paragraphs.text:
%md #MCS Algorithm to-date in SciSpark Purpose: This notebook will demonstrate using SciSpark to identify and track mesoscale convective systems (MCSs) in West Africa. Brightness temperature data is required to identify and track MCSs. For this demonstrations, first 9 days of hrly data in August 2006 of the brightness temperature NCEP/CPC MERG dataset over location 5S - 40N, 60E - 90W will be used. More information about the NCEP/CPC 4km MERG Dataset used for this demonstration can be found [here] (http://mirador.gsfc.nasa.gov/collections/MERG__001.shtml).
This environment contains all the classes and dependencies necessary to use SciSpark.By default we have loaded the SciSpark jar into the Zeppelin and Spark environment in the config folder. If you wish to do this manually or you are using the %pyspark env to acccess a jar, you will have to use the %dep as below. ``` %dep z.load("/data/cluster-local/software/zeppelin/local-repo/OrgDia.jar") ``` If you receive the following error: ``` Must be used before SparkInterpreter (%spark) initialized Hint: put this paragraph before any Spark code and restart Zeppelin/Interpreter ``` **Restart the spark interpreter and go again!**

result.msg:
MCS Algorithm to-date in SciSpark

Purpose: This notebook will demonstrate using SciSpark to identify and track mesoscale convective systems (MCSs) in West Africa. Brightness temperature data is required to identify and track MCSs. For this demonstrations, first 9 days of hrly data in August 2006 of the brightness temperature NCEP/CPC MERG dataset over location 5S - 40N, 60E - 90W will be used.

More information about the NCEP/CPC 4km MERG Dataset used for this demonstration can be found here.



This environment contains all the classes and dependencies necessary to use SciSpark.By default we have loaded the SciSpark jar into the Zeppelin and Spark environment in the config folder. If you wish to do this manually or you are using the %pyspark env to acccess a jar, you will have to use the %dep as below.

%dep
z.load("/data/cluster-local/software/zeppelin/local-repo/OrgDia.jar")

If you receive the following error:

Must be used before SparkInterpreter (%spark) initialized
Hint: put this paragraph before any Spark code and restart Zeppelin/Interpreter

Restart the spark interpreter and go again!

paragraphs.text:
%md 
##Step 1: Import Classes 
Both generic Scala & Java classes are needed, as well as SciSpark classes

result.msg:
Step 1: Import Classes

Both generic Scala & Java classes are needed, as well as SciSpark classes

import java.io.{File, PrintWriter}
import java.text.SimpleDateFormat
import org.slf4j.Logger
import scala.collection.mutable
import scala.io.Source
import scala.language.implicitConversions
import org.dia.Parsers
import org.dia.core.{SciSparkContext, SciTensor}
import org.dia.algorithms.mcc.MCCOps

paragraphs.text:
%md
##Step 2: Input user defined arguments
To run the MCS algorithm using netCDF data from HDFS, the following parameters are required:
* the number of paritions to use
* the variable in the netCDF files that represent the IR temperature
* the  HDFS path to the folder with data to use (NB: currently all the data at that location will be used)
By default the times for analysis will include all the times from the files at the HDFS path

We will pass this data as an array called *args*. You can update the values in *args*.

result.msg:
Step 2: Input user defined arguments

To run the MCS algorithm using netCDF data from HDFS, the following parameters are required:

  • the number of paritions to use
  • the variable in the netCDF files that represent the IR temperature
  • the HDFS path to the folder with data to use (NB: currently all the data at that location will be used)
    By default the times for analysis will include all the times from the files at the HDFS path

We will pass this data as an array called args. You can update the values in args.

paragraphs.text: val args = Array("6","ch4", "hdfs://128.149.112.134:8090/data/48hrs")//MCCTestData")

result.msg: args: Array[String] = Array(6, ch4, hdfs://128.149.112.134:8090/data/48hrs)

paragraphs.text:
%md
##Step 3: Set up the environment
* Update inputs required using the user-defined arguments
* Initialize the spark context to point to the master URL

result.msg:
Step 3: Set up the environment

  • Update inputs required using the user-defined arguments
  • Initialize the spark context to point to the master URL

partCount: Int = 6
varName: String = ch4
hdfspath: String = hdfs://128.149.112.134:8090/data/48hrs
dssc: org.dia.core.SciSparkContext = org.dia.core.SciSparkContext@5727786

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Step 4: Construct the sRDD
In this step the data is accessed from HDFS and paritioned into the **sRDD**.
Note that in the nomenclature used in this notebook, a *frame* indicates the date and time associated with a netCDF file.

result.msg:
Step 4: Construct the sRDD

In this step the data is accessed from HDFS and paritioned into the sRDD.
Note that in the nomenclature used in this notebook, a frame indicates the date and time associated with a netCDF file.

paragraphs.text:
val sRDD1 = dssc.NetcdfDFSFile(hdfspath, List(varName), partCount)

val labeled1 = sRDD1.map(p1 => {
    val source1 = p1.metaData("SOURCE").split("/").last.split("_")(1)
    val FrameID1 = source1.toInt
    p1.insertDictionary(("FRAME", FrameID1.toString))
    p1
})

result.msg:
sRDD1: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[org.dia.core.SciTensor] = MapPartitionsRDD[171] at map at SciSparkContext.scala:110
labeled1: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[org.dia.core.SciTensor] = MapPartitionsRDD[172] at map at <console>:131

paragraphs.text:
%md
##Step 5: Find cloud elements
The *cloud elements* are defined as contiguous areas that have a brightness temperature colder than 241K within a *frame*. As such a *frame* can have 0 or many *cloud elements*.

Notice the **sciTensor** datatype that is accessed in the sRDD through the map and flatMap functions to mask data and add metadata tags (the *frame*).

result.msg:
Step 5: Find cloud elements

The cloud elements are defined as contiguous areas that have a brightness temperature colder than 241K within a frame. As such a frame can have 0 or many cloud elements.

Notice the sciTensor datatype that is accessed in the sRDD through the map and flatMap functions to mask data and add metadata tags (the frame).

paragraphs.text:
val filtered1 = labeled1.map(p => p("ch4") <= 241.0)

val consecFrames1 = filtered1.flatMap(p => {
    List((p.metaData("FRAME").toInt, p), (p.metaData("FRAME").toInt + 1, p))
}).groupBy(_._1)
    .map(p => p._2.map(e => e._2).toList)
    .filter(p => p.size > 1)
    .map(p => p.sortBy(_.metaData("FRAME").toInt))
    .map(p => (p(0), p(1)))

result.msg:
filtered1: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[org.dia.core.SciTensor] = MapPartitionsRDD[173] at map at <console>:132
consecFrames1: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[(org.dia.core.SciTensor, org.dia.core.SciTensor)] = MapPartitionsRDD[180] at map at <console>:141

paragraphs.text:
%md
##Step 6: Connect the cloud elements between frames
In order to observe features are forming over time, it is necessary to connect *cloud elements* between *frames*. The connection, referred to as an *edge*, is created between *cloud elements* of consecutive *frames* if: 
* the area between consecutive frames is >= 2400.00 squared_km
OR
* the area between consecutive frames is < 2400.00 squared_km and the convective fraction is < 0.9. The convective fraction is defined as the ratio of miniumum to maximum brightness temperature

At the end of this step, a sparely connected graph representing the  cloud elements found and their connectivity through out the user defined datasets. 

Notice the **sciTensor** is being passed around and manipulated.

result.msg:
Step 6: Connect the cloud elements between frames

In order to observe features are forming over time, it is necessary to connect cloud elements between frames. The connection, referred to as an edge, is created between cloud elements of consecutive frames if:

  • the area between consecutive frames is >= 2400.00 squared_km
    OR
  • the area between consecutive frames is < 2400.00 squared_km and the convective fraction is < 0.9. The convective fraction is defined as the ratio of miniumum to maximum brightness temperature

At the end of this step, a sparely connected graph representing the cloud elements found and their connectivity through out the user defined datasets.

Notice the sciTensor is being passed around and manipulated.
componentFrameRDD1: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[((String, Double, Double), (String, Double, Double))] = MapPartitionsRDD[181] at flatMap at <console>:136

paragraphs.text:
%md
##Step 7: Collect the edges
This is the part where the graph is actually created. The edges indicate the connectivity between cloud elements from consecutive frames. The vertices indicate the cloud elements (contiguous areas with IR temp > 241K) from each frame. Each tuple in the sRDD represents (dateString, cloudElementNum, area).

result.msg:
Step 7: Collect the edges

This is the part where the graph is actually created. The edges indicate the connectivity between cloud elements from consecutive frames. The vertices indicate the cloud elements (contiguous areas with IR temp > 241K) from each frame. Each tuple in the sRDD represents (dateString, cloudElementNum, area).

paragraphs.text:
val collectedEdges1 = componentFrameRDD1.collect()
val collectedVertices1 = collectedEdges1.flatMap({ case (n1, n2) => List(n1, n2) }).toSet

val outvertices1 = new PrintWriter(new File("VertexList.txt"))
outvertices1.write(collectedVertices1.toList.sortBy(_._1) + "\n")
outvertices1.close()

val outedges1 = new PrintWriter(new File("EdgeList.txt"))
outedges1.write(collectedEdges1.toList.sorted + "\n")
outedges1.close()

println("NUM VERTICES : " + collectedVertices1.size + "\n")
println("NUM EDGES : " + collectedEdges1.length + "\n")

%md 
## Step 8: Visualize results
We will visualize the change of the cloud elements size over time using the Sql environment.
* a bar chart of the count of cloud elements at each time interval 
* a termite plot of the areas for the various cloud elements found at a given time.

result.msg:
Step 8: Visualize results

We will visualize the change of the cloud elements size over time using the Sql environment.

  • a bar chart of the count of cloud elements at each time interval
  • a termite plot of the areas for the various cloud elements found at a given time.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Step 8.1:
* Place the (collected) results into a RDD.
* Extract the required data to visualize into a data frame

result.msg:
Step 8.1:

  • Place the (collected) results into a RDD.
  • Extract the required data to visualize into a data frame

paragraphs.text:
val verticesRDD = sc.parallelize(collectedVertices1.toList)
case class CloudElement(time: String, uid: Int, size:Float)
val cloud_elements = verticesRDD.map({
    case(t1,t2,t3)  => CloudElement(t1, t2.toInt, t3.toFloat)
})

val data_frame = cloud_elements.toDF()
data_frame.registerTempTable("cloud_elems_table")

result.msg:
verticesRDD: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[(String, Double, Double)] = ParallelCollectionRDD[182] at parallelize at <console>:142
defined class CloudElement
cloud_elements: org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD[CloudElement] = MapPartitionsRDD[183] at map at <console>:146
data_frame: org.apache.spark.sql.DataFrame = [time: string, uid: int, size: float]

paragraphs.text:
%md 
### Step 8.2
To plot bar chart of the count of cloud elements at each time interval, select the time and the cloud elements from the data table

result.msg:
Step 8.2

To plot bar chart of the count of cloud elements at each time interval, select the time and the cloud elements from the data table

paragraphs.text: %sql select time, uid from cloud_elems_table

%md 
### Step 8.3
To plot a termite plot of the areas for the various cloud elements found at a given time, select the time, the cloud elements and their sizes from the data table

result.msg:
Step 8.3

To plot a termite plot of the areas for the various cloud elements found at a given time, select the time, the cloud elements and their sizes from the data table
